The tendency in Nebraska seems to be towards large and expen- § silos, and especially so towards large and expensive silage lling machinery. There may be good reason for this, but there 3 data at hand which shows that the large, powerful machines more efficient and more economical than smaller and less ex- pensive machinery. There are a great many farmers who would have silos if they knew that smaller machines are satisfactory and could be obtained. In emergencies, such as droughts or hail storms, the corn fodder could be saved if the farmers would take advantage of this type of machinery. INEXPENSIVE SILOS. There are two types of inexpensive silos which can be obtained upon very short notice. One is the pit silo and the other is the home-made, plain stave silo. The former can be made permanent while the latter is only for temporary relief, insomuch as the dry - ing winds of Nebraska will dry out the wood so fast that the silo is apt to blow down soon after it is emptied. INEXPENSIVE SILAGE MACHINERY. A corn binder is probably as satisfactory to use for cutting corn for the silo as any other machine. It is probably more expensive than any other method, unless it would be the common corn knife. The two row sled harvester with a device to prevent horses get - ting into the knives is probably the cheapest machine and the most economical for cutting corn for silage. The sled cutter is also very efficient in cutting corn for fodder. To handle this machine to the best advantage the wagons must pass along beside the har - vester so that as the men on the sled gather their arms full of corn they can lay it on the wagon. This saves laying it down and pick - ing it up again and it will be found that men can cut the corn and lay it on the wagon as fast as men can pick it off the ground and hand it up to men on the wagon for loading. tiere are two satisfactory machines which can be used for cut - corn and putting it into above-ground silos. One is a blower the other is the drag tube carrier. The former machine is the • expensive and requires about three times the power that is ired by the latter.
